questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury?
questions.correct_answer: A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.
  • ➤ In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation?

options.label: A
options.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.

options.label: C
options.text: Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.

options.label: D
options.text: Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.correct_answer: D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.
  • ➤ The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4 th and 5 th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.
  • ➤ The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4 th and 5 th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) McCune-Albright syndrome

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of being involved in a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft. The patient's condition was promptly stabilized. However, after a period of 12 hours, the individual experienced a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and the appearance of small reddish-purple skin rashes (petechiae) over the chest and underarm areas. What potential diagnosis could explain these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fat embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.
  • ➤ History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is an orthopedic emergency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Septic arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septic arthritis is a severe infection in a joint. It requires prompt medical attention to prevent permanent damage to the joint and even life-threatening complications. Thus, it is considered as an orthopedic emergency.
  • ➤ Septic arthritis is a severe infection in a joint.
  • ➤ It requires prompt medical attention to prevent permanent damage to the joint and even life-threatening complications.
  • ➤ Thus, it is considered as an orthopedic emergency.

questions.text: In Complete ACL rupture, the tibia moves over the femur in which direction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Forward

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ACL in the knee prevents forward sliding of the tibia on the femur. Thus, with complete rupture of the ACL, this forward sliding is not restrained, so the tibia moves in a forward direction on the femur.
  • ➤ The ACL in the knee prevents forward sliding of the tibia on the femur.
  • ➤ Thus, with complete rupture of the ACL, this forward sliding is not restrained, so the tibia moves in a forward direction on the femur.

questions.text: Most common injury in a 7-year-old child due to fall on outstretched hand is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Supracondylar fracture humerus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children, the most common injury due to fall on outstretched hand is the supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • ➤ In children, the most common injury due to fall on outstretched hand is the supracondylar humerus fracture.

questions.text: Nerve root for Ankle reflex is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) S1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nerve root for ankle reflex is S1.
  • ➤ The nerve root for ankle reflex is S1.

questions.text: Thomas splint is not used for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Infective arthritis of knee

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thomas splint is indicated most commonly for the fractures of the femur. Other indications include knee dislocations and other injuries around the knee. It is not indicated for septic or infective arthritis of the knee as it will not benefit in the infection healing, might only help with pain relief to some extent.
  • ➤ Thomas splint is indicated most commonly for the fractures of the femur.
  • ➤ Other indications include knee dislocations and other injuries around the knee.
  • ➤ It is not indicated for septic or infective arthritis of the knee as it will not benefit in the infection healing, might only help with pain relief to some extent.

questions.text: Which of the following arises in the medullary canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ewing's sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While all the above mentioned sarcomas affects bones, Ewing's sarcoma is the one that specifically targets the medullary canal of the long bones.
  • ➤ While all the above mentioned sarcomas affects bones, Ewing's sarcoma is the one that specifically targets the medullary canal of the long bones.

questions.text: Froment’s sign is positive in weakness of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thumb adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Froment's sign specifically targets weakness in thumb adduction, a function impaired by ulnar nerve damage.

questions.text: Most common type of supracondylar fracture in children is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posteromedial extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posteromedial extension describes the direction of the broken bone fragments. In supracondylar fracture of the humerus, the bone breaks and gets pushed backward (posterior) and slightly inward (medial). This is the most common pattern because of the anatomy of the elbow joint and the forces involved in the fall.
  • ➤ Posteromedial extension describes the direction of the broken bone fragments.
  • ➤ Posteromedial extension
  • ➤ In supracondylar fracture of the humerus, the bone breaks and gets pushed backward (posterior) and slightly inward (medial).
  • ➤ This is the most common pattern because of the anatomy of the elbow joint and the forces involved in the fall.

questions.text: Which part of spine is involved in Rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cervical

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most commonly involved spinal area in rheumatoid arthritis is the cervical spine, especially the upper cervical facet joints with atlanto-axial subluxation. Thoracic and lumbar spine are usually spared in RA.
  • ➤ The most commonly involved spinal area in rheumatoid arthritis is the cervical spine, especially the upper cervical facet joints with atlanto-axial subluxation.
  • ➤ Thoracic and lumbar spine are usually spared in RA.

questions.text: First symptom of fat embolism is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tachypnea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fat embolism syndrome symptoms typically develop 1-3 days after a major injury or surgery that releases fat into the bloodstream. The initial symptom of fat embolism is breathlessness/tachypnea, usually after 48 hours of the injury or the surgery.
  • ➤ Fat embolism syndrome symptoms typically develop 1-3 days after a major injury or surgery that releases fat into the bloodstream.
  • ➤ The initial symptom of fat embolism is breathlessness/tachypnea, usually after 48 hours of the injury or the surgery.

questions.text: Identify the nerve supply of the marked muscle:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Median Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image marks the 1 st lumbrical of the hand. The 1 st lumbrical is supplied by the median nerve.
  • ➤ The given image marks the 1 st lumbrical of the hand.
  • ➤ The 1 st lumbrical is supplied by the median nerve.

questions.text: In the fracture shown in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brachial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture which is mostly associated with the brachial artery injury.

questions.text: What surgery can be done for CTEV at 2 years of age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Soft tissue release

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 2 years of age, the bones are still developing, and soft tissue release is often sufficient to correct the foot deformity. This procedure involves releasing tight tendons and ligaments to allow the foot to be repositioned into a normal alignment.
  • ➤ At 2 years of age, the bones are still developing, and soft tissue release is often sufficient to correct the foot deformity.
  • ➤ This procedure involves releasing tight tendons and ligaments to allow the foot to be repositioned into a normal alignment.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and discharging pus from right thigh since 3 months. Following is the X-ray. Identify the labeled structured:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Involucrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum . It has some holes to drain out pus, called as cloaca . Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.
  • ➤ The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum . It has some holes to drain out pus, called as cloaca .
  • ➤ involucrum
  • ➤ cloaca
  • ➤ Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.
  • ➤ Sequestrum

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly define Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?

options.label: A
options.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

options.label: B
options.text: Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

options.label: C
options.text: Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint

options.label: D
options.text: Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.correct_answer: A. Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3 rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.
  • ➤ Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3 rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: A patient with raised serum alkaline phosphatase and raised parathormone level along with low calcium and low phosphate level is likely to have:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin D deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The raised ALP and PTH levels are seen with vitamin D deficiency.
  • ➤ The raised ALP and PTH levels are seen with vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: Arthritis involving DIP, PIP, 1st carpometacarpal with sparing of MCP and wrist joints is typical of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The involvement of DIP, PIP and 1 st CMC with sparing of the MCP and wrist joints is seen in the osteoarthritis of the hand.
  • ➤ The involvement of DIP, PIP and 1 st CMC with sparing of the MCP and wrist joints is seen in the osteoarthritis of the hand.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with history of back pain since 3 months. ESR is raised. On Examination, there is tenderness of dorsolumbar region and mild restriction of chest movements is found. On X-ray, syndesmophytes are present in vertebrae. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ankylosing hyperostosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given complaints of the patient of increased ESR, dosrolumbar region pain and tenderness with mildly restricted chest movements and, the elder age group of the patient are suggestive of presence of ankylosing hyperostosis, which is different from ankylosing spondylitis.
  • ➤ The given complaints of the patient of increased ESR, dosrolumbar region pain and tenderness with mildly restricted chest movements and, the elder age group of the patient are suggestive of presence of ankylosing hyperostosis, which is different from ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: In screening of neonatal hip instability, most commonly used modality is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) USG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neonatal hip instability or developmental dysplasia of hip, USG is the investigation of choice to evaluate the cartilaginous structures in the hip. It is more subjective than MRI.
  • ➤ In neonatal hip instability or developmental dysplasia of hip, USG is the investigation of choice to evaluate the cartilaginous structures in the hip.
  • ➤ It is more subjective than MRI.

questions.text: In slipped capital femoral epiphyses, slip occurs in which direction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posteromedial

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE) is a condition where the head of the femur slips backward and downward (posteromedially) at the growth plate.
  • ➤ Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE) is a condition where the head of the femur slips backward and downward (posteromedially) at the growth plate.

questions.text: The following pelvic X-ray was seen in a patient. All the following signs will be present except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gaenslen sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows developmental dysplasia of hip in a child. DDH can be clinically diagnosed by tests like Ortolani’s test, Barlow’s test, vascular sign of Narath etc. Gaenslen’s test is a provocative test for SI joint lesions in adults. It is not used in children.
  • ➤ The given image shows developmental dysplasia of hip in a child.
  • ➤ DDH can be clinically diagnosed by tests like Ortolani’s test, Barlow’s test, vascular sign of Narath etc.
  • ➤ Gaenslen’s test is a provocative test for SI joint lesions in adults. It is not used in children.

  • ➤ Sensitivity: They are usually present during an acute attack.

  • ➤ Definitive diagnosis: Confirms the clinical suspicion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV patient on antiretroviral therapy complains pain in right hip since 2 months. He has deformity of flexion, abduction and external rotation. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TB Hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The patient's hip pain, deformity of flexion, abduction, and external rotation , along with their HIV status, raises the suspicion for TB hip . TB should always be considered in HIV-infected individuals, particularly when they present with chronic musculoskeletal complaints such as joint pain and deformity. The insidious onset, systemic involvement, and the gradual progression of symptoms are all hallmark signs of tuberculous arthritis .
  • ➤ The patient's hip pain, deformity of flexion, abduction, and external rotation , along with their HIV status, raises the suspicion for TB hip .
  • ➤ deformity of flexion, abduction, and external rotation
  • ➤ raises the suspicion for TB hip
  • ➤ TB should always be considered in HIV-infected individuals, particularly when they present with chronic musculoskeletal complaints such as joint pain and deformity.
  • ➤ The insidious onset, systemic involvement, and the gradual progression of symptoms are all hallmark signs of tuberculous arthritis .
  • ➤ tuberculous arthritis

questions.text: Posterior glenohumeral dislocations occur more frequently than anterior dislocations in which group of patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epileptics

Ans. C)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding spinal tuberculosis?

options.label: A
options.text: It originates underneath the anterior longitudinal ligament and can cause destruction of several contiguous levels.

options.label: B
options.text: It can cause skip lesions at non-contiguous segments in 15% of the cases.

options.label: C
options.text: In the early disease process, the disc spaces are relatively preserved.

options.label: D
options.text: Kyphosis and Pott paraplegia are late sequelae.

questions.correct_answer: A. It originates underneath the anterior longitudinal ligament and can cause destruction of several contiguous levels.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spinal tuberculosis arises from the anterior part of the vertebral body and not underneath the anterior longitudinal ligament. It can cause skip lesions at the non-adjacent vertebrae in about 15% cases. In the early process of the disease, the disc space is relatively preserved in the affected vertebra. With advancement of the disease and due to delayed treatment, there is development of kyphosis and paraplegia.
  • ➤ Spinal tuberculosis arises from the anterior part of the vertebral body and not underneath the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • ➤ It can cause skip lesions at the non-adjacent vertebrae in about 15% cases.
  • ➤ In the early process of the disease, the disc space is relatively preserved in the affected vertebra.
  • ➤ With advancement of the disease and due to delayed treatment, there is development of kyphosis and paraplegia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male is involved in a road traffic accident sustaining a fracture-dislocation of the cervical spine. He has absent motor function, absent sensation and anal tone. The bulbocavernous reflex is intact. Which of the following best describes this spinal cord injury pattern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Complete spinal cord injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Based on the presented symptoms i.e., absent motor function, absent sensation, absent anal tone, intact bulbocavernosus reflex, a complete spinal cord injury is the most accurate diagnosis.
  • ➤ Based on the presented symptoms i.e., absent motor function, absent sensation, absent anal tone, intact bulbocavernosus reflex, a complete spinal cord injury is the most accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: Core decompression following avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head is more likely to be successful if the patient has not progressed beyond?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) FICAT II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Core decompression for reducing the femoral head vascular pressure is useful in AVN of hip only in the pre-collapse stages according to Ficat classification. Stage 1 and stage 2 are pre-collapse stages while stage 3 and stage 4 are post-collapse, where hip replacement surgery is the treatment of choice.
  • ➤ Core decompression for reducing the femoral head vascular pressure is useful in AVN of hip only in the pre-collapse stages according to Ficat classification.
  • ➤ Stage 1 and stage 2 are pre-collapse stages while stage 3 and stage 4 are post-collapse, where hip replacement surgery is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following inserts into the talus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Talus bone does not have any muscular attachment because of its limited blood supply and lack of any secondary blood supply.
  • ➤ Talus bone does not have any muscular attachment because of its limited blood supply and lack of any secondary blood supply.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to your clinic with progressively increasing pain in her left wrist. She has also recently been having repeated episodes of abdominal discomfort, nausea and vomiting. A plain radiograph of the wrist reveals an eccentrically placed lytic lesion in the metaphysis and epiphysis with thinning of the cortex. You suspect a giant cell tumour of bone. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Curettage, high-speed burr, cement and bone graft

options.label: D
options.text: Check serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium

questions.correct_answer: D. Check serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Check serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On suspecting giant cell tumor, further confirmatory investigation in the form of checking the levels of serum PTH and calcium should be done because brown tumors caused by hyperparathyroidism mimics GCT radiographically. The presenting symptoms of abdominal discomfort, nausea and vomiting are sometimes related to hyperparathyroidism. Thus, serum PTH and calcium levels must be checked first and then the other treatment options can be performed.
  • ➤ On suspecting giant cell tumor, further confirmatory investigation in the form of checking the levels of serum PTH and calcium should be done because brown tumors caused by hyperparathyroidism mimics GCT radiographically.
  • ➤ The presenting symptoms of abdominal discomfort, nausea and vomiting are sometimes related to hyperparathyroidism.
  • ➤ Thus, serum PTH and calcium levels must be checked first and then the other treatment options can be performed.

questions.text: The diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis include all of the following except?

options.label: B
options.text: Limitation of motion of the lumbar spine

options.label: C
options.text: History of pain in the lumbar spine

options.label: D
options.text: Limited chest expansion to 2.5 cm or less

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HLA B27 positivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis includes limitation of the lumbar spine movements, history of lower back pain, and limited chest expansion (< 5 cm).
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis includes limitation of the lumbar spine movements, history of lower back pain, and limited chest expansion (< 5 cm).

questions.text: Which one of the following benign tumours can metastasize to the lung?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chondroblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Out of the given options, chondroblastoma have potential of metastasis. It usually metastasizes to the lungs. Though, its metastasis is rarely seen.
  • ➤ Out of the given options, chondroblastoma have potential of metastasis.
  • ➤ It usually metastasizes to the lungs.
  • ➤ Though, its metastasis is rarely seen.

questions.text: Following clubfoot surgery, which of the following is the commonest residual deformity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Forefoot adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-operative clubfoot treated with Ponseti method, there are chances of recurrence of clubfoot or presence of under-corrected foot deformities. The most common post-surgical residual deformity of the clubfoot is the forefoot adduction.
  • ➤ In post-operative clubfoot treated with Ponseti method, there are chances of recurrence of clubfoot or presence of under-corrected foot deformities.
  • ➤ The most common post-surgical residual deformity of the clubfoot is the forefoot adduction.
